message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn presents with clitoromegaly and posterior labial fusion, and the electrolyte levels suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). Increased 17-hydroxyprogesterone is the most likely finding in CAH. Decreased renin activity is seen in cases of salt-wasting CAH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn presents with clitoromegaly and posterior labial fusion, indicating congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The serum studies show high levels of potassium, which is a hallmark of CAH. 17-hydroxyprogesterone is produced in the adrenal gland and is elevated in CAH. The other options are not typically associated with CAH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn's presentation is consistent with a congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This is supported by the presence of clitoromegaly and posterior labial fusion, as well as the electrolyte disturbances. Among the options, increased 17-hydroxyprogesterone is the most commonly used marker for CAH due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. The other options are not specific to this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn's clitoromegaly and posterior labial fusion suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), specifically 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This causes increased 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels. The other options are not characteristic of CAH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clitoromegaly and labial fusion suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). CAH is commonly due to a deficiency in one of the enzymes required for the biosynthesis of cortisol, leading to increased ACTH levels and subsequently increased androgen production. Increased 17-hydroxyprogesterone is a characteristic biochemical finding in most cases of CAH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn's signs and laboratory findings suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). Among the options, only increased 17-hydroxyprogesterone is associated with CAH, specifically with the most common form of CAH, 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn's presentation suggests congenital adrenal hyperplasia. The elevated potassium level and ambiguous genitalia are consistent with a deficiency of 21-hydroxylase, which results in decreased cortisol and aldosterone synthesis and increased androgen synthesis. Increased 17-hydroxyprogesterone is a marker of 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Clitoromegaly and posterior labial fusion suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The serum electrolyte levels and normal ultrasound of the uterus and ovaries suggest the 21-hydroxylase deficiency variant of CAH. Among the options, increased 17-hydroxyprogesterone is a characteristic finding in this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn's symptoms suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Increased 17-hydroxyprogesterone is a diagnostic marker of CAH. Decreased dehydroepiandrosterone and increased corticosterone are not commonly associated with CAH. Decreased renin activity is not relevant to the diagnosis of CAH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clitoromegaly and posterior labial fusion suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The elevated potassium level confirms this, as well as the low sodium level. Increased 17-hydroxyprogesterone is characteristic of the most common form of CAH, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme 21-hydroxylase. The other options are less likely to be elevated in CAH.
